passage: Genome editing technologies, such as CRISPR-Cas9, TALENs, and ZFNs, have revolutionized the field of genetics. However, the success rate of these editing methods may vary significantly, depending on factors such as the research group and the specific technique employed.
question: Which choice best describes data from the table that support the statement about varying success rates?

choices.A: Smith & Johnson and Gupta & Kim both used CRISPR-Cas9, but the success rates of their studies varied by 15-20%.
choices.B: Martinez et al. used TALENs and reported a success rate range between 30-50%, which was the highest among all research groups.
choices.C: O'Connor & Lee used ZFNs and achieved a success rate of 25-40%, while all other research groups using different methods reported success rates above 60%.
choices.D: Gupta & Kim used CRISPR-Cas9 and achieved a success rate range of 60-80%, which was similar to the success rate ranges reported by all other research groups.

explanation: A: 'Smith & Johnson and Gupta & Kim both used CRISPR-Cas9, but the success rates of their studies varied by 15-20%.' is the correct answer because it accurately describes the data from the table and supports the statement about varying success rates of genome editing methods depending on the research group and technique.
distractor_explanation: 'Martinez et al. used TALENs and reported a success rate range between 30-50%, which was the highest among all research groups.' is incorrect because the highest success rate range was reported by Gupta & Kim using CRISPR-Cas9.

'O'Connor & Lee used ZFNs and achieved a success rate of 25-40%, while all other research groups using different methods reported success rates above 60%.' is incorrect because Martinez et al. reported a success rate range of 30-50%, which is not above 60%.

'Gupta & Kim used CRISPR-Cas9 and achieved a success rate range of 60-80%, which was similar to the success rate ranges reported by all other research groups.' is incorrect because the success rate ranges of other research groups were lower than that of Gupta & Kim.
